author: soispoke
content:
I think it’s quite healthy to hear different opinions on whether an upgrade should be included or not. I also agree devs should be able to experiment and focus on whatever they think is the most important. 

But those considerations are a bit out of what really matters here, which is the realisation that ePBS does include different, separable components (e.g., the beacon block/payload separation, the auction) and while there is a relatively broad agreement on block/payload separation, the auction doesn’t have to necessarily be tied to it/shipped at the same time? I’ve heard you say many many times that the auction is not that important or not the central/crucial part of the EIP, so maybe the most productive discussion moving forward would be to see if we can make progress on block/payload separation and find the very best way to do it (future proof, efficiency gains, compatibility w/ other upgrades, etc…)? I think it’s important to realise efforts are actually going in the exact same direction: separating the beacon block from the payload would be a great unlock if we can do it right and I can imagine that would actually happen quite fast if both <@520034910149410861> and <@755590043632140352> get behind it tbh (+ any other folks interested in joining the effort obviously). 

I also think there is no intention to discard or bring down the great work that’s been put into by the current version of ePBS until now (including Teku as you mentioned).  I also agree the roadmap, as much as we want to idealise it, is not fixed and very much dynamic and changing constantly, not only from a technical/idea perspective but also from what’s top-of-mind these days I also feel like it’s annoying sometimes but can’t really do much about it.

author: soispoke
content: Oh and very anecdotal note but I also don’t really think opposing FOCIL and ePBS all the time is very productive, they address different issues and shouldn’t really be competing in any way unless we find unsolvable incompatibilities (which is not the case afaik).

author: potuz
content: I repeat, separating the payload from the block as in this EIP is essentially all of the EIP, the doing it without the PBS part amounts to actually complicating it by adding a single line "enforce builder=proposer". There may be other ways of separating the block from the payload that I am unaware about, my point is that this has gone past the research stage, and if someone has a better way of separating the payload from the block and can be implementable in simpler terms than this EIP, I'm happy to listen/watch it being implemented. I simply don't know a way. Doing it the way of this EIP, and removing the ability for the payload signature to differ from the proposer signature is just not right and not justifiable.

author: potuz
content: Since people bring the "forkchoice complication" as an argument quite often: the complication relies from the fact that you have to deal with blocks that may not have a payload. You have to deal with this situation no matter if the proposer is self building or not, so if we use the separation of this EIP, forkchoice will have to face this fact no matter what. Removing the auction part is an extra requirement, not less requirements.

author: potuz
content: All the safetly mechanisms to not allow the next proposer to reorg the payload have to be in place, etc... The auction is off-protocol from this EIP.

author: m.kalinin
content:
I don't know where "treating it like it's included" is coming from in this case (possible from some other place). But breakout call, clients and devops time investments should definitely not be treated as a signal for inclusion. It is totally fine (and even great) if any team (including devops) can decide to invest their time into working on some feature accepting a risk that this feature may never be shipped. A breakout call seems to be an indicator of the fact that the interest in any feature (not only ePBS) has spread across several parties and it makes sense to start coordinating their efforts. If it were not this way, i.e. it was prohibited for teams to work on anything that is not in the roadmap and have breakout calls, it would be hard to move new complex features towards shipping them.

On the ePBS side of things, I am a proponent of minimalistic CL/EL separation and decomposition of ePBS into this minimal functionality + the auction on top of it. It makes a lot of sense to me, because the separation itself unlocks more benefits than just ability to introduce payload auction.
